instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Green light on charger goes on and off. 

The board works fine when connected to a programmable PSU. it allso works fine with battery only.
Tried with known good DC-in board same result
No visible damage to the board.

Would really appreciate if someone pointed me in the right direction:)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Allso with lab PSU it draws 35 mA (without battery)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Your case looks like input leakage.
Original Apple charger is smart enough to detect it and gets blocked.
Usually bad <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>, sometime <DIODE>D6910</DIODE>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi, thank you for the warm welcome:)

Changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and board now ok. Is there any way to measure if this is the faulty component?

Thanks again for the assistance :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Measuring <RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR>/81 and <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>/86 onboard values can help.
